issues.text: Whether the decision of the Government of Andhra Pradesh treating US and OCE certificates of the Osmania Engineering College as inferior to and not equivalent to LCE, LME, LEE diplomas or US/LCE of Guindy is erroneous and should be set aside?

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Government of Andhra Pradesh contained in the orders dated 3rd October, 1960 and 14th February, 1963-confirmed by the Government of India by its letter dated 17th March, 1966-treating US and OCE certificates of the Osmania Engineering College as inferior to US and LCE diplomas of the College of Engineering, Guindy and LCE, LME or LEE diplomas of any other recognised institution and equating them with LS or OCE certificates of the College of Engineering, Guindy was erroneous and should be set aside.

issues.text: Whether the application of the Andhra Rules and enactment of the Andhra Pradesh Rules varied to disadvantage the condition of service regarding promotion applicable immediately prior to 1st November 1956 to non-graduate Supervisors from Hyderabad without previous approval of Central Government under proviso to section 115(7) of States Reorganisation Act, 1956?

Whether promotion from Supervisors to Assistant Engineers constituted 'one stage promotion' governed by Hyderabad Rules by virtue of order dated 7th April 1960 and rule 42(h)(i), requiring review of promotions made under Andhra Rules?

Whether the Andhra Pradesh Rules discriminate amongst different categories of non-graduate Supervisors by reserving vacancies in cyclic order for promotion to Assistant Engineers, contravening Article 14?

anchor.surface_text: The Andhra Pradesh Rules in so far as they discriminate amongst different categories of non-graduate Supervisors by reserving a vacancy for each category of non-graduate Supervisors in the cyclic order of rotation for the purpose of promotion in the posts of Assistant Engineers contravene the equality clause contained in article 14 and are to that extent void.

issues.text: Whether the Andhra Pradesh Rules discriminate between graduate Supervisors and non-graduate Supervisors by fixing ratio of three to one for promotion to Assistant Engineers, violating Article 14?
Whether a change in ratio of promotion vacancies affects 'conditions of service' under proviso to S.115(7) or merely chances of promotion which are unprotected?

Whether the Central Government's memorandum dated 11th May 1957 provides general previous approval for variations in conditions of service relating to departmental promotion under proviso to S.115(7)?

arguments.claim: Application of Andhra Rules and enactment of Andhra Pradesh Rules varied conditions of service regarding promotion to disadvantage without previous approval under proviso to s.115(7) States Reorganisation Act
arguments.court_reasoning: Change affected only chances of promotion, not right to be considered which is the protected condition of service; cites precedents distinguishing right from chance

arguments.claim: Even if variation, Central Govt memorandum dated 11th May 1957 did not provide previous approval for changes in promotion conditions under proviso s.115(7)
arguments.court_reasoning: Memorandum gave general previous approval for variations in departmental promotion conditions; follows Raghavendra Rao precedent, overrules later distinguishing cases

arguments.claim: Promotion from Supervisors to Assistant Engineers is one stage promotion governed by Hyderabad Rules per order 7th April 1960 and rule 42(h)(i); promotions under Andhra Rules need review
arguments.court_reasoning: Sub-Engineer cadre abolished; no equation with Assistant Engineer for promotion purposes; Hyderabad Rules do not provide direct promotion Supervisor to Assistant Engineer; rule 42(h)(i) inapplicable

arguments.claim: Andhra Pradesh Rules discriminate amongst categories of non-graduate Supervisors by cyclic reservation violating Article 14

anchor.surface_text: The Andhra Pradesh Rules in so far as they discriminate amongst different categories of non-graduate Supervisors by reserving a vacancy for each category of non-graduate Supervisors in the cyclic order of rotation for the purpose of promotion in the posts of Assistant Engineers contravene the equality clause contained in article 14 and are to that extent void.

arguments.court_reasoning: Reasonable classification based on qualifications and experience differences permitted under Article 14 twin test

arguments.claim: Andhra Pradesh Rules discriminate between graduate and non-graduate Supervisors by 3:1 ratio violating Article 14
arguments.court_reasoning: Reasonable classification recognizing differences in qualifications; rational relation to promotion object under Article 14

anchor.surface_text: Article 14 ensures to every person equality before law and equal protection of the laws... the right to classify. For it is the classification which determines the range of persons affected by the special burden or benefit of a law which does not apply to all persons.

holdings.text: The decision of the Government of Andhra Pradesh treating US and OCE certificates of the Osmania Engineering College as inferior to and not equivalent to LCE, LME, LEE diplomas or US/LCE of Guindy is not erroneous and should not be set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Government of Andhra Pradesh contained in the orders dated 3rd October, 1960 and 14th February, 1963-confirmed by the Government of India by its letter dated 17th March, 1966-treating US and OCE certificates of the Osmania Engineering College as inferior to US and LCE diplomas of the College of Engineering, Guindy and LCE, LME or LEE diplomas of any other recognised institution and equating them with LS or OCE certificates of the College of Engineering, Guindy was erroneous and should be set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Decision based on expert State Board of Technical Education; not irrational, perverse, mala fide or manifestly arbitrary; even in Hyderabad not treated at par; court defers to expert body on technical equivalence.

holdings.text: It is not possible to overturn the decision denying equivalence of US and OCE certificates of Osmania Engineering College with LCE, LME or LEE diplomas.

anchor.surface_text: irrational or perverse, and in any event, it was not shown by the petitioners that US and OCE certificates of the Osmania Engineering College were equivalent to LCE, LME or LEE diplomas and accordingly dismissed the writ petitions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Comparison of course duration/content shows inferiority; historical treatment in Hyderabad confirms; Central Govt affirmed.

holdings.text: Application of Andhra Rules and Andhra Pradesh Rules did not vary conditions of service to disadvantage under proviso to s.115(7) SRA as they affected only chances of promotion, not right to be considered.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes protected right to consideration from unprotected chances; cites precedents like Purohit and Deodhar.

holdings.text: Change in promotion ratio affects mere chances of promotion, not conditions of service under proviso to s.115(7).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Right to be considered is condition; chance is not; ratio change reduces opportunities but not right.

holdings.text: Central Government memorandum dated 11th May 1957 constitutes previous approval for variations in conditions of service relating to departmental promotion under proviso to s.115(7).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms Raghavendra Rao; disapproves Bhakar, Vaid, Bahadur as misreading; general approval valid in context of Art.309.

holdings.text: Promotion from Supervisors to Assistant Engineers is not 'one stage promotion' under Hyderabad Rules; governed by Andhra Rules; no review required.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-Engineer cadre abolished post-reorg; no direct promotion Supervisor to AE under Hyderabad; rule 42(h)(i) inapplicable.

holdings.text: Andhra Pradesh Rules reserving vacancies cyclically among non-graduate Supervisors categories do not contravene Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: The Andhra Pradesh Rules in so far as they discriminate amongst different categories of non-graduate Supervisors by reserving a vacancy for each category of non-graduate Supervisors in the cyclic order of rotation for the purpose of promotion in the posts of Assistant Engineers contravene the equality clause contained in article 14 and are to that extent void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reasonable classification based on qualification/experience differences; satisfies twin test of rational nexus to promotion object.

holdings.text: Andhra Pradesh Rules fixing 3:1 ratio between graduate and non-graduate Supervisors do not violate Article 14.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Permits classification recognizing qualification differences; equal protection allows reasonable differentiation.

anchor.surface_text: particularly the decision in Mohammed Bhakar v. Krishna Reddy 1 where this Court, speaking through Mitter, J., said Any rule which affects the promotion of a person relates to his condition of service. But when we speak of a right to be considered for promotion, we must not confuse it with mere chance of promotion-the latter would certainly not be a condition of service.

precedents.cited_proposition: Any rule which affects the promotion of a person relates to his condition of service, but right to be considered for promotion must not be confused with mere chance of promotion, which is not a condition of service.
precedents.cited_holding: Any rule which affects the promotion of a person relates to his condition of service.

precedents.citation: State of Mysore v. G. B. Purohit 2

anchor.surface_text: This Court point out in State of Mysore v. G. B. Purohit 2 that though a right to be considered for promotion is a condition of service, mere chances of promotion are not. A rule which merely affects chances of promotion cannot be regarded as varying a condition of service.

precedents.case_name: State of Mysore v. G. B. Purohit
precedents.cited_proposition: Right to be considered for promotion is a condition of service, but mere chances of promotion are not.
precedents.cited_holding: chances of promotion are not conditions of service

p1 holds that any rule affecting promotion relates to condition of service and right to be considered, directly supporting the concept c13 of right to be considered for promotion as protected condition
p2's holding matches a9's statement on right to consideration as condition but chances not
p2 explicitly states 'Right to be considered for promotion is a condition of service, but mere chances of promotion are not', directly supporting c13
p3's view on rules affecting only chances supports a9's argument that ratio change affects only chances
p3 holds that a rule merely affecting chances of promotion is not a condition of service, supporting the distinction in c13 between right to consideration (protected) and mere chances (not)
